segments.text: And I was born here in Laredo, Webb County, Texas.
My father is the late Mercury Martinez, who is originally from San Ignacio, Zapata County, Texas.
And my mother came from the old town of Guerrero, Tamaulipas, Mexico.
And her name was Cristina Treveño.
You would like to have a little information about my father.
About your father.
All right.
Yes, I'd like to know more about your father.
Perhaps you could just begin with a short account of his life as you know it.
Well, my father...

was the son of Proceso Martinez, who married one of the original descendants of the original settlers of the old town of San Ignacio in Zapata County, Texas, by the name of Maria Jesus Uribe, who was the daughter of Don Jesus Uribe.
My grandfather used to be a merchant.
It is said that he was the one that originally introduced the plow and also the lantern into this South Texas area at that time by the fact that he was a merchant and brought in many of these things.
Prior to that time, all they used were camels.
My father was educated or received his...
primary education in the old town of San Ignacio.
And from there, and against the wishes of his father, Don Proceso, he decided that he was going to get his formal schooling by going to Austin, Texas and registering at St. Edward's University.
Why did his father not want him to do that?
Because at that time, they believed that
They had more than enough work.
They believed in the ranch life.
And with the primary schooling that they had was more than enough.
How many years was this?
This was about eight, 10 years of actual schooling that he had received.
So basically against the wishes of his father, but with the full support of a man that my father
became very close to, and that was Mr.
A.M. Bruni.
And Mr.
A.M. Bruni guaranteed his education, or at least if he needed any help, that he would make sure that he would provide him with the necessary funds, which he did.
And I understand that after he got his education, my father was able to repay every penny that he borrowed from Juan Antonio at the time.
But he decided to go to St. Edward's College, and he was able to get his what is referred to at that time as Master of Accounts degree.
He graduated in 1898 from St. Edward's College.
From there, he came to San Ignacio, and he started teaching in the old settlement of Dolores in Zapata County.
There he thought for about 10, 12 years, at which time he decided to get a little bit more involved in politics, and he ran for county treasurer, which he was elected.
It was during this time, I understand, that the elections got so hot that my father had a prize on his head
And they were gunning for him.
Who was gunning for him?
Well, some of the opposing candidates.
What party did your father represent?
Well, he represented the party that was being headed by the old judge, A.P.
Spahn.
And it got to the point that whenever he would go to bed, he would fix his bed in one corner, and after he would turn off the lamp,
he would move his bed to the opposite corner just in case.
And his horse was so well trained that it would follow him wherever he would go.
And he used to relate one comment or one little story.
He said one time this friend of his made a bet that if he would go through this particular house, that the horse wouldn't follow him.
And he took him up on it.
So he got off the horse and went into the main room, which was considered, you might say, the living room.
The horse followed, went into the dining room, the horse followed, went into the kitchen, the horse followed, and on through the kitchen, and the horse was right behind him.
That's how bad politics was at the time, and he just wanted to make sure that he had his method of transportation so he'd need to ride on all of a sudden.
Where was he living during the election?
Was he still in Dolores?
He was in San Ignacio at the time.
He had gone to San Ignacio.
He had gone to San Ignacio.
And after he got elected, of course, he went and lived in Zapata, the old town of Zapata.
And he was there.

for up until the time that he moved down here to Laredo, at which time he started working as an investigator and overall troubleshooter, including, I would say, bookkeeper, interpreter for the old law firm of Hicks, Hicks, Dixon, and Bobbitt.
And this was in the 1920s, late 1920s.
I think he still continued to have a very active role in the local politics, primarily in Zapata County, and he never really lost touch of it because people really respected him considerably.
Probably I would imagine the reason why he loved politics so much is his father was a county commissioner for 30 years.
That was Don Proceso.
And then after Don Proceso retired, then his son, Proceso Jr., who was younger than my father, was elected county commissioner.
And he was a county commissioner in Zapata for another 30 years.
So I guess this is part of the reason.
The politics was in his blood, and he always lived it.
But he related most interesting times
So to go back to an earlier question, you said that A.M. Bruni helped him go through college.
Now, how did your father get acquainted with A.M. Bruni?
Well, when Don Antonio first came here from the old country, from Italy, my father used to buy quite a number of what we referred to as or skins for
Mr. Bruni, who in turn, Mr. Bruni, would sell further up in the east.
Were these cattle skins?
Cattle skins and primarily cattle skins.
And over the years, he was able to, and again, too, by the fact that my grandfather was a merchant in San Ignacio.
He had a store in San Ignacio.
This was also part of the friendship that developed over that period of time.
And after my father got out or graduated from St. Edward's, this relationship continued.
And on a number of occasions, as I mentioned to you a little earlier, my father was used.
He was a go-between, you might say, to buy land for Tony Bruni.
And this, of course, was done primarily to keep the original sellers or the original owners of the land from hiking the prices on that land.
When they found that it was Bruni who was... Who was the one that was actually interested in buying the land.
Yeah, well, tell the story about Bruni's land and their extent.

Well, my father used to relate that Mr. Bruni had so much land that a man would start at the crack of daybreak, crack of dawn, ride on horseback, which was right on the edge of the river, and ride out all day long.
And this would be hard riding on horseback.
And it'd get dark, and he would still be riding on Bruny land.
That's how much land A.M. Bruny had accumulated over his lifetime.
As a matter of fact, when Mr. Bruny died, my father still had under his name, as you might say the owner, 5,000 acres of land.
And nobody else in the family of Mr. Bruni knew about the acquisition of these 5,000 acres of land.
But my father was so honest that after the funeral, he approached my father, approached the heirs, primarily Antonio Chico, as he used to refer to.
And he told Antonio Chico, he said, listen, I have 5,000 acres that are under my name, but
do not belong to me.
I bought them with your father's money.
And as soon as you have everything settled, let me know so that I can deed these 5,000 acres of land over to you and the family."
And this is the type of honesty that he had.
He just was very much what we sometimes refer to as a straight shooter.
And it got to a point, especially later on,

in actual documentation or knowledge for family trees and land titles that time and again my father was used to as a witness by both defense attorneys and counselors he was used as a key witness and none of the attorneys would ever challenge whatever he would

say, you know, whenever he came, whenever he was put on the stand in land matters or land titles, neither party, neither party of either instance would ever challenge him because that's how well versed he was and that's how well respected
the respect that he had from all of the attorneys, because they knew that whatever he would say was actually the actual truth.
And through his testimony, there were many land titles that were settled and never challenged, primarily on his say-so, on his words.
How did he happen to become involved with this Laredo law firm?
Was there an incident that led to this?
The incident that led to this was that his older brother, who used to have a creamery, used to have San Andres Dairy at the time.
Which brother was this?
This was a brother by the name of Serafin.
Excuse me, not Serafin.
It's an older brother.
Adolfo, excuse me.
Adolfo Martinez.
And one early morning when he got up to milk the cows, and he stepped on a puddle.
And while he was on the puddle, he went on to turn the light.
So he got electrocuted.
So my father, who was in Zapata at the time, came over and started doing some investigation work in order to bring his findings.
And he used the law firm of Hicks, Hicks, Dixon, and Bobbitt.

And the firm was so impressed in the manner that he conducted this investigation that Mr. Bobbitt, Judge Bobbitt, Robert Lee Bobbitt, as a matter of fact, and Yale Hicks, they offered him a position with the law firm.
Of course, after that, he worked for 20 years with the law firm.
And during this time, he was used to a great extent
to investigate family trees and land titles.
And it was during this time that he got to learn even more so about names, dates, places, family trees.
And this, to him, was a school in itself, as he used to make reference.
And after that, there were many people that thought that he was an attorney, which in fact he was not.
But they would always come to him for all simple wills and deeds of trust.
Well, he was a notary public.
He was a notary public.
But he definitely was not an attorney, even though many people still think that he was.
But he did acquire this association in the mind of his friends and relatives.
That's right.
helped them, apparently, with quite a bit of legal work.
To go back again to some of the early history, one of the questions that I had was about your father's first wife, not Guadalupe Uribe, his second wife.
But the first- Maria Uribe, who was a sister of Guadalupe Uribe.
They were both sisters, and they were first cousins of my father.
And she died right immediately after childbirth.
There was only one reference.
There was one child, the baby, of course, that died a few weeks later.
And then he married.
How long had they been married?
for a relatively short period of time.
Short time.
This was the first child.
The very first child.
Maria died.
I would say probably just over a year at the most.
Did he ever talk about that at all?
Very little.
He didn't write it into his papers either.
No.
And then he married this other sister who was the oldest in the family.
She was several years older than he was.
Quite a number of years older.
He was married to her or lived for several years, quite a number of years.
As a matter of fact, they
They were the ones that moved over from Zapata County to Laredo and built the house on 416 Lincoln.
It was in the late 1920s.
Do you live there now?
That's where I presently live.
At 416 Lincoln.
I just wondered.
Yes, ma'am.
So that's the mother house, you might say, or the father house.
The father house.
And after she died, then she married my mother.
How did he meet your mother?
Well, my mother came from Olzapata to work for my father because my father, well at the time, that my aunt Lupita was sick, she was extremely sick, so she came over to care for her.
And after she died, my aunt Lupita.
Your father's second wife.
My father's second wife.
Right, okay.
And we call her Tia Lupita.
But anyway, this is how the relationship started.
And after she died, then a short while later, my father married my mother.
Were they also kin?
No.
Well, probably they were kin, but there were quite a few distantly related.
Quite a few degrees.
In other words, practically everybody from San Ignacio and Guerrero all through there is connected in one way or another.
One way or another.
The relationship came from the Gutierrez family because my mother was a Gutierrez, so.
That's where that relationship came from.
And out of that union, only my sister and I were born.
Now, your mother, Christina, had been married once before, had she not?
She had also been married twice before.
But she only had a child from one of those marriages.
And so I have a half-sister.
Where does she live?
She's presently living in Corpus.
While I'm thinking about it, where's Rosa living now?
Rosa is living right across from where I live at 413 Lincoln Street.
Has she married?
No.
No, she says that she's not about to support somebody.
She's two years younger than I.
At least her intentions right now are not too bad.
What year were you born?
I was born in 1937, July 25.
You're exactly one year younger than I am.
Is that right?
All right.
Well, let's see.
There were several things that I particularly wanted to ask.
Oh, while I'm thinking about it, I don't have the date of your father's death.
When did he die exactly?
I don't have it with me.
And I'm afraid I cannot.
Like I say, I'm not good at dates.
But I'll find out, and I'll be more than happy to tell you about it.
All right.
What year was it?
I wasn't sure of that either.
But you can write me about it.
Just 10 days before he was to complete his 90th year.
So he was 89 years old.
89, just 10 days shy of 90.
90 years old.
This was in August.
I'm afraid I can't, I don't recall the date.
Well, the men in your family are notably long-lived.
I'm afraid they are.
Judge.
The oldest, well, the latest one that died, let me put it this way, he died just about a little better than a year
almost two years ago.
And he was almost 98 years old when he died.
Which one was that?
Who was older?
And that was one of your father's brothers?
Brother, who was older than my father.
So it's true.
I mean, they're a strong fiber.
You've got good genes for staying around a long time.
Well, back to your father, after he retired from the law firm, one of the things he apparently did was work for the Boundary Commission.
Could you tell me a little bit about the nature of his work with the Boundary Commission?
Well, this was during the time that the International Boundary and Water Commission was going to build Lake Falcon.

and they needed somebody that was well-versed with the families in the affected area that was well-versed with the titles land titles and also that was well-versed with the family trees within the area and because of that and of course by the fact that my father was already up in years he was already in his 70s
They waived their requirement that they have to go through for civil service.
And he was hired.
And he conducted a considerable amount of investigation with regards to who should be paid and the amounts.
And he was also the arbiter.
He would come in as far as the settlement of many of the lands
the different families and the different heirs.
And through him, and primarily because of him, the greater part of all of that acreage was finally settled.
Because he was a type that would devote a considerable amount of time to detail.

And he was very meticulous and he would trace it all the way from the original grand tour in order to prove his point as to who was the original or the owner that should be paid or that settlement should be made.
Well, in some cases, have these lands simply not been subdivided?
That is correct.
They were still being held in common by all the descendants?
Exactly.
And this is where my father's, I would say, invaluable knowledge came through.
And there was a number of occasions I know that I myself personally would drive him to many of these old ranches
where he would conduct personal interviews in order to clear a particular error or in order to find who the other issues were within the family.
And in his reports, many times he provided family trees, which he would in turn turn over to the International Boundary Water Commission.
So his help proved to be invaluable
in trying to make final settlement for the Falcon.
Now how did he feel about the Falcon situation?
Do you remember?
He believed in it because he felt that this would bring in a boom to the area which
Let's face it, the agricultural economic area had been going down considerably, and he felt that the lake would provide particularly a tourist industry, which in effect it has.
And consequently, this is one area that he believed quite strongly.
The only one that he opposed, and he was able to oppose quite favorably, was the moving of San Ignacio.
Again, primarily through his efforts, San Ignacio was left there.
And I'm glad that it was, because all of the original houses, stone houses, like the old fort where they used to find Indians, and the original settlements, all of that definitely has been preserved.
And he was the one that was initially contacted to get the International Boundary Water Commission
and change its plans, which they did.
Now, what was his particular reason for justifying the salvation of San Ignacio?
Well, to a great extent, of course, he used the historical interest.

And then he used the surveys that were done by the Boundary Commission as far as the altitude, which, let's face it, San Ignacio is in a much higher area, or the altitude there is much higher than the old Zapata.
So it really wasn't going to be submerged.
Not at all whatsoever.
It has never been, not even in the latest flood, which was in 1954, and it was proven because it definitely did not reach San Ignacio.
I mean, it was around it, but it didn't get at San Ignacio.
So his point was well taken and well proven.
Now, a lot was said.

One of his very convincing arguments that he's left in his papers was that the terrible hardship that would be created by these people if they had to leave the homes of their ancestors and if they had to give up
their lands that were along the river.

Now, this, of course, was certainly very poignant, and he also pointed out that many of them might end up just, you know, going elsewhere, and maybe they couldn't even make a way for themselves, and he talked about their independence and this sort of thing, but to turn this around, this, of course, was true for San Ignacio, but what about the people of Old Zapata?
Were they as socially disrupted as
He argued the people of San Ignacio would have been.
You must keep in mind that old Zapata had already been moved about two different times prior to that.
So, in effect, we were not really talking about the original settlements.
Because prior to that time, there used to be what they would refer to as the Carrizo.
which was later changed to Zapata.
And it was even further downriver.
So in effect, we're not talking about a town that had the historical meaning that San Ignacio has.
And true, there were some old stone houses there, but it definitely did not carry the historical background of San Ignacio.
And to this extent, that's why we really did not carry the impetus or the catalyst or the influence that San Ignacio now definitely has.
This is the main, main reason why.
There was some talk at the time of putting, or at least some people in San Ignacio, excuse me, New Zapata, wanted to put two dams on the Rio Grande which would lower the level of the lake.
Do you remember where your father stood on that particular issue?
Because they were the two proposals, one to just keep the level, build a lower dam and another one upstream and save old Zapata too.
Well, I'm afraid that I don't recall any comment from him along those lines.
Well, that was rather, that was in the late 1940s.
That was a little earlier.
I didn't start really helping him out until the 1950s when he was actually hired.
Because he was hired by the Boundary Commission in the 50s, after he already had retired in the 40s from the law firm of Hicks, Hicks, Hicks, and the Boundary.
Yes, ma'am.
So you were in your early teens.
Yes, ma'am.
When you were, well, not that early teens.
You were 16 or 17.
Just about.
I was already in high school at the time.
Well, your father, in his work with the people down there, did he do anything to make the transition any easier for them that you recall, the ones who did have to move?
Yes, and because of his influence and because of the trust that they had in him, that he was able to influence many of the people that didn't want to move from their ranches.
I don't know, I guess...
We must keep in mind that my father, who most, I mean, they had deep respect for him.
And normally, what he would say, they wouldn't challenge.
Again, his influence was used by the government to a very great extent, and he was definitely instrumental in getting many of these people moved out from their ranches and from their old settlements.
Well, he wrote a corrida called The Ballad of Old Zapata,
which is a very beautiful piece of work, full of the emotional trauma of having to uproot even from old Zapata.
Did he write many other things like this?
He did.
And as a matter of fact, I have some compositions of his over at my home.
And I only wish I had the ability to recite them as well as he did.
But they are written.
And he does have them in his own personal handwriting.
And again, that flavor, that emotion does come through along those lines.
Well, in the difference between Spanish and English, do you feel that he used the two different languages differently?
True, I would say so, because, I don't know, there seems to be a little bit more flavor
The adjectives are a little bit more meaningful in Spanish, and of course the fact that that's his native tongue, he had more...
direct contact with that particular language.
Spanish is the first language he learned.
That is correct.
When he went to school in San Ignacio, was education there in English or Spanish or both?
Or do you know?
It was mostly in Spanish.
Mostly in Spanish.
So they were actually being taught.
Bilingual education is not new.
That's right.
At least not as far as he was concerned.
And did he learn some English in school there, or did he learn English later?
Some English.
Some English.
Not that much.
He really didn't learn it until he went over to St. Edward's at Austin.
In which language would you say he was the more fluent?
Or was he equally fluent?
He was equally fluent in both because he had the ability, while reading English, he was reading it, you might say,
how shall I say, silently.
But as he was reading it in, let's say, English, he was actually saying it out loud in Spanish.
And vice versa, he would read something in Spanish, but he would be reading it out loud in English.
He really was quite fluent in both, which is something that I never was able to acquire.
I haven't either.
But he was quite instrumental.
And I guess that's the reason, too, why a number of times he was used as a court interpreter, because he was fluent in both.
Well, what language did you grow up speaking at home?
Spanish.
My mother didn't know any English at all, so all we spoke at home was Spanish.
And not until, well, the
The time that we went to school, all my formal schooling is in English.
I never got any formal education in Spanish.
But at home was strictly Spanish.

How did your father, and he was as I see him, of course, and I'm interpreting him from his papers, but he strikes me as being a man who in some ways lived in two worlds, very much a part of what you might call the Anglo-North American United States world, also very much a part of what, of course, was also
the United States, but had been part of Mexico since he was very much a native Texan, but still one with much more of a Spanish-Mexican culture.
Do you feel like he synthesized these worlds in his personality, or did he see them as two different worlds?
And I'm being a little introspective here.
That's a hard question to answer, but I, as far as I was concerned, he felt very, very much at ease.
in the situation.
He was definitely never the type to, I don't think, he ever felt that he was ever discriminated, let's say.
On the contrary, he always had their respect, or everybody's respect, for that matter.
They always referred to him as Don Mercurio, with the utmost respect.
Of course, as far as I was concerned, to me,
He was already quite elderly when I finally gained some kind of reason.
And by that time, of course, everybody knew him, and he was very well respected.
And regardless of who it was, the respect always was there, including by my mother, who used to call him Don Mercurio.
Don is being very...
how shall I say, with the utmost respect.
In address of honor.
In address of honor.
There you are.
Well, is this partly the Laredo situation?
Do you think Laredo is different, say, from other towns on the border?
I would say so.
How would you say it's different?
Because I don't, Laredo, I have never been exposed as such, you might say, outside of the Laredo, other than the times that I've been working on my
well, former schooling when I was doing graduate work outside of Laredo and North Texas and in Colorado and even in Massachusetts.
But by the fact that we've never been exposed to any kind of discrimination, we don't look for it.
We don't have a chip on our shoulder, and consequently, we just don't believe in it.

because we haven't been exposed to it i would imagine well now do you think that's partly because of the influence of men like your father in the early history i'm sure that that is the case you definitely don't see it here in the right no you don't see it no not at all and uh this is this is something this will help me understand your father better perhaps that this particular situation in laredo was there any historical reason that this that it happened this way that there was a kind of synthesis
I would imagine one time I went into some kind of discussion along these lines when I told him that I didn't believe in this discrimination bit.
And to as far as I was concerned, it didn't exist.
It still doesn't.
And this individual told me, yes, but you must keep in mind that your background
is entirely different by the fact that you came from people that inherited land, that were well-respected, that had the image of supposedly cultured people.
And consequently, the kind of an attitude that you received was probably very, very different than from other families.
That might have been the case.
I don't know.
So he was arguing that it's your family situation rather than Laredo itself that is different.
That's what he was arguing.
But you wouldn't agree with that?

I definitely do not, because I know even close friends here that did not have or does not have the, did not inherit, let's say, land or things along these lines, and they do not have that kind of an attitude.
It was quite different in El Paso, and I was surprised.

I did not know that for El Paso, but apparently there was a tremendous amount of discrimination in El Paso and directed toward people who were from good families, so this would tend to support your argument.
What about further down in the valley?
What do you know about those towns, say, to compare them, in this respect, with Laredo?
I'm afraid I have never been, I've never lived in the valley.
Just going through it, the extent of my knowledge would be Zapata in Zapata, Texas, and that would be about as far as that situation is concerned.
But isn't that really part of the Laredo culture, if you will, Zapata culture?
Very much so, with Laredo.
Is this the case?
Or with the valley you're talking about?
No, I mean Zapata ties in more with Laredo.
Very, very much.
Zapata ties in very strongly because the greater number of the people from both of these towns, they came from the old Guerrero, Tamaulipas, and they're the ones that settled this area.
And including Nuevo Laredo, too, for that matter.
Mm-hmm.
And this is probably the reason why.
If the greater number of the people here, you will find that one way or another they're related.
Or there's some kind of tying in, probably possibly even by marriage.
But at least there's something that makes a connection somewhere.
Wasn't Bruni's wife from one of the Spanish families?
Yes, ma'am, she was.
She married a local woman.
local woman here, and who was very well respected.
That is correct.
That's right.
And that was true of Martine?
That was true of Martine, or Martin as they now referred to, who the present mayor, Mayor J.C. Martin, is one of the descendants.
But all of these people, and by the way, Mayor J.C. Martin was also, is also a grandson of A.M.
Again, we come back again to the same families.
A lot of intermarriage.
Quite a bit.
What about the new people?
They are very well accepted here in Laredo.
And many people have mentioned this, that Laredo opens up quite well to the people that move from out of town, which I think is the case.
And we are just quite friendly.
That's a feeling, that to a point, the greater number of the people, they really get to love the town here, because within a relatively short period of time, they get to know most everybody.
And they are greeted on a very friendly basis.
Well, did your father ever talk about his move to Laredo?
Did he ever wish he could move back to San Ignacio?
No.
On the contrary, he said that that was the
best blessing that he ever did in moving down here to Laredo.
Because he never sold his properties in Zapata.
He kept them.
And he kept on farming.
He had some agriculture out there.
It was dry farming.
But he kept on working the land out there.
At the same time, he was able to improve his financial situation by moving down here to Loreto.
So he definitely was, I would say, grateful in the sense that he decided to move down.
And he made a good decision.
That's the way he felt.
That's the way he felt, because he was able to acquire a few pieces of property here.
He didn't feel like it was too big a town or anything?
No, not at all.
Maybe because of the small-town atmosphere?
No, no, because, like I say, he knew most everybody, and most everybody knew him.
He was quite well-respected in Laredo.
Well, you've talked about his basic honesty.
Do you have any more, oh, the lots in Zapata?
When old Zapata was moved, you said that he could have acquired more land than he did.
Well, in the old town of Zapata, he had some very, very choice lots.
Some of them that were right in the heart of the downtown, you might say, Zapata.

And by the fact that he worked with the International Boundary Water Commission, he very well could have acquired, along the same lines, choice properties that surrounded the courthouse, that were right by the highway.
But yet he decided that he was only going to ask for one lot and get
the proper remuneration for those lots for the rest to the laws that he had so he definitely did not or was not the time to take advantage

and this is a basic honesty that he had because that's the way he believed in now when land was or when the lots were given in replacement were people given lots that corresponded to the same position next to the square as their lots in the old town that this was the their intent whose idea was this do you know
To a great extent, he was influential there.
He was?
Yes, ma'am.
Well, I'm very glad.
How did he happen to have this idea?
Well, he felt that you must keep in mind that the old settlements were normally built around
the courthouse and the square.
And the closer you were, naturally, that was a kind of respect again that you had.
It was a matter of prestige where you lived in relation to the square, which is very old Spanish and Mexican.
Very much so.
Yes.
And this is the same influence that he had as far as trying to do the same thing in moving to the new town of Zapata.
And the relationship or the distance of these lots was how far you are from the courthouse.
And you will notice that that's the case over there in the new town of Zapata.
Well, I just wondered if the government might have had other plans if he hadn't suggested it.
Well, that was a possibility.
Because some of the records indicate that people in Old Zapata said they would move, they would exchange their lot if they could have a lot that was in the same relationship to the square.
And he must have passed this information on and convinced people how important this was.
Oh, very important to them.
It was most important.
Do you happen to know if this was done in New Guerrero?
I'm afraid I don't.
I don't have any idea how they worked it out in New Guerrero.
I do know that people are still living in Old Guerrero that never moved to New Guerrero.
With the flood water?
I mean, with the dam and the lake water?
Well, they live in the higher area of Old Guerrero, and it would be an interesting tour
if you should ever have the time, because you still see the cobblestone roads there, and you still see many of the old...
